metadata.title: Nanomaterials as potential and versatile platform for next generation tissue engineering applications

sections.text:

This review article gives a comprehensive outlook of different organ specific NMs which are being used for diversified TE applications. Varieties of NMs are known to serve as biological alternatives to repair or replace a portion or whole of the nonfunctional or damaged tissue. NMs may promote greater amounts of specific interactions stimulated at the cellular level, ultimately leading to more efficient new tissue formation. © 2019 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Biomed Mater Res Part B: 00B: 000–000, 2019.
Key Words: growth factors, nanobiomaterials, regenerative medicine, scaffolds, tissue engineering

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Most of the diseases cause loss of organ function or tissue damage and increase the risk of mortality in patients.1
Transplantation of organs from one individual to another or from the animals has been accepted as the vital therapeutic approach used for decades. There are three basic steps in tissue engineering (TE). The first step deals with getting the base cells from the donor to work with. The second step is related to the expanding of the cells in culture and subsequently putting the altered cells into a scaffold in order to incubate the cells. The final step is to implant the newly created cells or organ into use (Figure 1).
TE is rapidly emerging as a novel medical strategy for repair, replacement, and regeneration of damaged tissues and organs in the human body, but the lack of donors limits
the application of transplantation.2 A new therapy came into origin that involved in the injection of cells into the injured site. The cellular therapy faced the limitations such as cell death before the cell–cell or cell–matrix interactions; additionally, there is no control over the injected cells as they fail to reach the site of damaged organ.3 These shortcomings led to evolution of a new field of TE. With the advancement of TE, it was aimed to develop 3-D scaffolds or such biomaterials that should mimic the natural extracellular matrix (ECM) of tissues so that the cells could easily attach and proliferate to regain the normal function after being seeded onto these TE biomaterials.4 TE deals with combination of organ transplantation, material science, and engineering discipline which aided in development of regenerative medicines.5
In view of all these advancements, there is still need for
Briefs: Nanomaterials play the crucial role in tissue engineering via design of biomaterial scaffolds to provide controlled cell adhesion, modulation of the spatial organization of cells in the scaffolds, and propagation of tissue development and formation. This review article summarizes the description of different organ specific nanobiomaterials. Correspondence to: A. Acharya; e-mail: amitabhachem@gmail.com, amitabha@ihbt.res.in Contract grant sponsor: CSIR and GAP-0214; contract grant number: EMR/2016/003027
© 2019 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. 1
synthesis of better materials as the typical scaffolds that were proposed to mimic the natural environment have some limitations such as these are not biocompatible, have low mechanical strength and these do not provide proper vascularization required for the growing cells.6
Nanotechnology-based approaches have been used recently to design simple nanosized materials to further develop complex substances for usage in TE applications and to biomimic the natural environment of cells.7 NMs possess better physical and chemical properties and have superior biocompatibility as compared to bulk molecules from which these are synthesized. The properties of NMs can be altered easily by modifying the fabrication process and method of assembly.8 NMs consist of nanotubes, dendrimers, nanofibers, nanoparticles (NPs), nanowires, and many other nanostructural forms.9 Nanotechnology-based materials can be synthesized to release and deliver important growth factors or bioactive molecules to the targeted damaged organs/tissues.10,11 There are literature reports where carbon nanotubes (CNTs), electrospun nanofibers formed from synthetic or natural polymers, fullerenes, nanodiamonds, nanocomposites, metal NPs incorporated in the polymeric scaffolds have been used as implants for TE in in vivo and in vitro systems.12–14 However, rare data are available demonstrating the applicability of such NPs in human or clinical studies. NMs formulated through nanopatterning or nanofabrication techniques provide the surface and most suitable environment for the growth of cells. In the present review, we emphasize on providing the outlay of different kinds of organs (bone, skin, liver, pancreas, cartilage, heart, etc.) where the TE is involved. The different treatment therapies involved in the past and the limitations associated with them for tissue regeneration is also discussed. A detailed description is also provided related to various nanotechnologybased materials applied for tissue regeneration.

sections.heading: DESIRABLE PROPERTIES OF NMS FOR TE
sections.text:
A variety of nanomaterials (NMs) have recently been used as scaffolds for the TE of different organs and/or tissues like skin, bone, cartilage, cardiac, liver, corneal, neural, pancreas, and so on. TE mainly revolves around three main pillars that
consist of material scaffolds, cells and growth factors/bioactive molecules. Figure 2 summarizes the overall process of TE how it deals with these three basic components. The examples of different NMs used in the recent past for their prospective in TE and regenerative medicine have been represented in Table I. The properties of NMs taken into account for TE include various factors, namely, (1) nanodimensions impart proper structure to cells/tissues for their adhesion, differentiation, and proliferation; (2) NMs serve as analogous structures to ECMs in terms of chemical composition and physical structure15,16; (3) due to their excellent mechanical strength, NMs can act to reinforce various organic/synthetic scaffolds for TE17; (4) high conductivity of carbon-based NMs provide electrical stimulation to scaffolds for bone engineering18,19; (5) micro/nano encapsulation of important growth factors help them to release in a slow and sustained manner at the target site20,21; and (6) NMs impart better biocompatibility, bioactivity, and enhance interactions of scaffolds to cells or proteins.22

REVIEW ARTICLE

sections.heading: SKIN TE
sections.text:
Skin is the largest organ of human body that acts as a barrier to protect internal organs from the pathogens occurring in the external environment. Skin also helps in thermal regulation and moisture retention to the whole body.23 In order to perform its function well, skin has a tendency of continuous repair and regeneration depending upon several types of stem cells present in it.24 Damage to skin due to burns, acute wounds, accidental, or pathological (diabetes) foot ulcers lead to skin impairment.23 Thereafter, TE came into play to design appropriate skin substitutes, artificial ECM, and a source of cells by understanding the morphology of damaged skin tissue and stem cells in order to restore the lost anatomy and physiology of skin.25 Skin TE involves the cells delivered on their own to the target, delivery of cells along with developed biomaterials, materials used for replacement of dermal layer of skin, and the substances that assist in the replacement of epidermis and dermis of skin.26 Skin tissue replacements must be readily adherent, should possess good physical and mechanical properties, and be nonantigenic.27
Designing of scaffolds for skin TE require the adequate knowledge about wound healing events, types of wounds, pathological conditions of patients, mechanism involved in healing and optimal properties of an ideal dressing.
For skin TE, conventionally, a large variety of biomaterials have been taken into use. Examples of such natural biomaterials include collagen, hydroxyapatites, alginates, chitin, cellulose, fibronectin, chitosan, hyaluronan, gelatin, polypeptides, and glycosaminoglycan. These biomaterials have the excellent advantage of having low toxicity and a low chronic inflammatory response. A variety of synthetic materials have also been used for skin TE that includes poly(lactide-co-glycolic) acid (PLGA), poly(ε caprolactone) (PCL), polylactic acid (PLA), and polyglycolide. Synthetic polymers offer advantages such as low cost and can be characterized readily as compared to natural materials. However, these materials lack cell recognition signals and, consequently, there are few cell interactions.28,29 To circumvent all the associated problems with novel approaches in delivering specific outcomes such as wound closure, control of fluid loss, providing strength to the healed tissue, and histocompatibility, researchers have led to the introduction of nanotechnological approaches, as the properties of materials change remarkably at nanometer scale. Even if a small quantity of nanosized materials is incorporated into any other polymeric matrix, the performance of the resultant nanocomposites
(in terms of mechanical and thermal stability) is improved to an unprecedented level.30 Nanocomposites, hydrogels, scaffolds, and dressings in various other forms have been prepared from different types of NMs such as inorganic, polymeric, carbon-based, and solid lipid NMs for skin repair and regeneration due to their versatility, high surface area to volume ratio, great interaction with the biological target, ease of surface modification, high chance of penetration in the skin tissue, and ability to control physicochemical properties.31 Among the inorganic NMs used for wound healing, metal and metal oxide NPs (silver, gold, zinc, etc.) play a great role. Silver (Ag) has been used as a therapeutic agent for the treatment of wounds for ages, but the therapeutic effect of nano-Ag has been claimed to enhance the wound repair when compared to conventional Ag or ionic Ag dressings. Because of the antimicrobial nature of silver NPs (AgNPs), AgNPs-based dressings against a broad spectrum of microbes impart infection free wound healing of burn wounds, incision, and excision skin acute as well as chronic wounds.32,33 A report showed that the use of nano-Ag (3–10 nm size) gel synthesized from whole cell and cell free extract of different microbes promoted healing of burn wounds as compared to marketed formulations and silver ions.34 Manufacturers and suppliers of a variety of nano-Ag dressings available in the market have claimed that these dressings show slow and controlled release of Ag ions to wound site. Such dressings are also declared safe and noncytotoxic for human use as the released AgNPs do not penetrate deep inside the skin while they accumulate at the dermal part of skin, helping in covering the wound milieu with keratinocytes growth.35 AgNPs has an antiinflammatory role that affects the cytokine modulation (IL-6, IL-10, MMPs, and PMNs) in the early inflammatory phase of wound healing.36 AgNPs are also known to bring alteration in fibroblasts structure and suppress fibroblasts proliferation by its differentiation into myofibroblasts, decreasing the expression of collagen type-I which is further responsible for rapid wound contraction and ultimately re-epithelization.37
In other studies, copper, AuNPs, ZnO, titanium dioxide (TiO2), and magnetic NPs have been embedded in few scaffolds to improve their mechanical strength required for skin TE. These metal NPs possess strong antibacterial activity, photocatalytical activity, high surface area, and high drugloading capacity make these potential candidates for skin tissue repair.38,39 Magnetite NPs providing high specific surface area and lower internal diffusion resistance loaded with
4 SINGLA ET AL. NANOBIOMATERIALS FOR TISSUE ENGINEERING APPLICATIONS
biopolymers serve as promising tools for scaffold-mediated construction of 3D engineered tissues composed of magnetic controlled orientation of cells and ECM.40
Nanocomposites prepared from different materials also have the potential to serve as dressings for skin tissue repair. Depending upon its components, that is, dispersion medium and dispersed fillers, these tend to increase the mechanical strength of the wounded tissue. In this respect, copper containing glass/eggshell membrane nanocomposites improved the angiogenesis and antibacterial activity in mice for wound healing.41 Nanocomposites containing polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and multiwalled CNTs (MWCNTs) conjugated to glucose oxidase have been known to act as scaffolds for wound healing.42 Wanna et al.43 demonstrated the use of kaolin–bacterial cellulose nanocomposites as a wound healing material. Kaolin was supposed as a blood clotting agent that served as a short-term wound healing material whereas nanocellulose having potential of water adsorption will serve as a long-term material. Apart from this, cellulose nanofibers have been incorporated with AgNPs to develop nanocomposites possessing dual function of water retaining capacity for long, along with the antimicrobial activity.37 The authors demonstrated the wound-healing potential of the developed nanocomposites in second degree burnt wound rat model for 28 days. In vivo and histopathological studies demonstrated that AgNPs containing cellulose possess excellent healing potential. Biocompatible dressing of plant cellulose nanocrystals impregnated with AgNPs has also been reported to promote acute wound healing in mice as compared to several controls used in the study. The complete wound closure was observed in less than 14 days due to an increase in angiogenesis, collagen deposition and reepithelization after topical application of the developed NMs.38 Similarly, few more types of nanocomposites such as chitosan–bentonite,44 chitosan–polyvinylpyrrolidone–TiO2 NPs,45 chitosan/polyethylene oxide along with chitin nanocrystals46 have been used as scaffolds for wound repair that enhance the tensile strength of the skin tissue as compared to controls.
Biodegradable and biocompatible nature of polymeric materials provided an unique opportunity to serve as the polymeric scaffolds for tissue repair.47 Among the variety of polymeric compounds, bacterial cellulose hydrogels play a great role, as it is biocompatible, highly porous, and possess high surface area to volume ratio which provide nucleation site for the attachment of collagen and helps in tissue growth. Bacterial cellulose has a tendency to retain moisture in its structural pores for longer duration.48 The presence of moisture at the wounded site helps in the process of re-epithelization during the fibroblasts proliferation so as to strengthen the healing paradigm. Another important polymeric chitosan NPs were loaded in calcium alginate hydrogels. Addition of chitosan NPs increased the antibacterial activity against gram-negative bacteria and also increased the production of ROS. In vivo studies in mice showed that chitosan NPs loaded hydrogels promoted proliferation of vascular endothelial cells, ultimately led to rapid skin wound healing and re-epithelialization.49 Another report demonstrated the use of gelatin NPs for the loading and release
of doxocetal drug at the wound site. The gelatin is known to control the fluid loss resulting in rapid healing. Drug loaded into gelatin NPs gets released as gelatin degrades due to enzymatic action.50
Nanoencapsulated bioactive molecules also served as promising approach for skin TE. NPs encapsulated with bioactive ingredients help in slow and sustained release of active moiety to the target site and also increase the stability of molecules.51 As an important natural molecule, curcumin suffers from limitations of poor solubility and fast degradation rate that hinders its applicability as antioxidative and antimicrobial agent. To overcome these limitations, curcumin-loaded NPs have been synthesized that enhanced the wound healing in murine model as compared to pure curcumin.52 In another report, efforts have been made to prepare curcumin-loaded chitosan NPs which were then impregnated into collagen– alginate scaffolds. Such prepared nano-scaffolds resulted in complete epithelization and granulation tissue formation for rapid healing of wounds in diabetic mice.53 Likewise, fibrinbased scaffolds has been developed to incorporate the NPs of important growth factors, that is, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and fibroblast growth factor (FGF) to stimulate diabetic wound healing in mice.54 Similarly, recombinant human endothelial growth factor has been encapsulated in lipid NPs for faster and effective healing of diabetic wounds.55
A bioactive peptide LL34 encapsulated in nanostructured lipid carriers has been reported to improve the healing of chronic wounds as LL34 possesses antibacterial activity. The bioactive peptide LL37 loaded into PLGA NPs has improved the angiogenesis and resulted in accelerated wound repair.56

sections.heading: BONE TE
sections.text:
Bone is a nanofibrous structure of calcified connective tissue composed of mainly collagen reinforced with hydroxyapatite arranged in a hierarchical manner. Bone tissue provides mechanical strength, support body structure and also protect bone marrow. Bones possess the capacity of repair and regeneration. However, large bone defects like bone fracture resulted from osteoporosis or arthritis, trauma, bone cancer, high impact force and stress, need bone grafts. The transplantation of bone tissue is highly frequent and the treatment of nonhealing bone defects requires replacement graft (autografts or allografts).57 Treatment of bone defects by bone graft technology suffers from limitations like lack of availability of donors and also donor site morbidity. The use of TE approaches deals with manufacturing of 3D scaffolds having composition similar to natural bone tissue. The huge clinical demand of bone TE to restore the normal function of defected bone tissue has been increasing over past few decades. Due to the natural nanostructure of bone, many nanotechnology-based materials have been designed to mimic bone functions with an aim to help bone formation and increased integration into the host tissue.58 The controlled and targeted delivery of bone regenerative factors can be accomplished via NMs carrier systems to facilitate local repair at the defect site.59 Active molecules such as drugs, growth factors, hormones, and peptides are quite
JOURNAL OF BIOMEDICAL MATERIALS RESEARCH PART B: APPLIED BIOMATERIALS | MONTH 2019 VOL 000B, ISSUE 0 5
REVIEW ARTICLE
unstable at certain temperatures, water insoluble in nature and degrade quickly. In this context, nanoencapsulated active molecules show high tendency to be used as materials for bone regeneration. Chitosan NPs encapsulated with dexamethasone has been reported for use in bone formation, as these tend to promote the osteogenic differentiation of stem cells due to sustained delivery of dexamethasone from NPs.60 Another polymer-hydrogel complex consisting of heparin functionalized PLGA NPs were loaded with bone morphogenetic protein (BMP-2). The NPs complex has enhanced the remodeling of new bone formation, suggesting the role of this complex as a bone replacement matrix due to its potential of sustained delivery of BMP-2.61 In another report, human parathyroid hormone-loaded PLGA NPs have been incorporated in chitosan–gelatin hydrogels for bone regeneration. In vitro PTH release kinetics from PLGA NPs showed a burst release followed by a slow release phase for 3–4 weeks.62 In another case, 2-N, 6-O-sulfated chitosan NPs have been incorporated with BMP-2 peptide. The developed nanocomplex acted as implant and resulted in enhanced vascularization and also promoted bone augmentation.63 A similar report has demonstrated the formation of dual drug delivery system based on chitosan functionalized mesoporous silica NPs carrying BMP-2 and dexamethasone for bone defect repair. Synergistic action of dual drug delivery system enhanced the osteogenic differentiation and also led to bone formation in vivo.64 Likewise, silica NPs loaded with boneforming peptide has also shown enhanced osteogenic differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) due to release of peptide from NPs, that suggested their role as promising candidates for bone tissue repair.65
Nanocomposites play a pivotal role in bone grafting as a new class of bone graft material, which uses a combination of several nanoscale bone graft materials and/or in conjunction with osteoinductive growth factors and osteogenic cellular components. In another study, successful fabrication of porous nanocomposite scaffolds of poly(glycerol sebacate)/nanosilicates was done. The scaffolds supported preosteoblast proliferation, increased cell adhesion, spreading, and osteogenic differentiation without any osteogenic supplements, suggesting their osteoinductive capability. Moreover, the nanocomposites scaffolds were biocompatible, biodegradable, and did not induce persistent inflammation in in vivo systems66,67
(Figure 3). Nanocomposite scaffolds mat of electrospun poly (3-hydroxybutyrate) (PHB) nanofibers and hydroxyapatite NPs documented, that on 21-day monitoring, human MSCs showed continuous proliferation useful for bone TE.68 In another report, composites of PHB nanofibers in combination with TiO2 NPs and chitosan oligomers have been found to be biocompatible and also caused the development of MSCs suitable for bone TE.69 Water-soluble chitosan play the roles of both stabilizing the nano-TiO2 dispersions and serving as a sticking agent for the nano-TiO2 particles onto PHB fibers. Nano-TiO2 exerts a favorable effect on the process of cell proliferation. The topography of the developed hybrid materials and the presence of TiO2 exerted a favorable impact on cell adhesion and growth. Likewise, poly(3-hydroxybutyrate-co-3-hydroxyvalerate) (PHBV) nanofiber scaffolds were incorporated with hydroxyapatite NPs
and showed differentiation of MSCs into osteoblasts and also exhibited repair of critical bone defects in rabbit radius.70
Hydroxyapatite is known to displayed osteoconductive and “inherent” osteoinductive effect. MSCs attached and proliferated more favorably on random-oriented PHBV nanofibrous meshes without hydroxyapatite while introduction of hydroxyapatite led to osteogenic differentiation of MSCs. In a different study, the effect of hydroxyapatite and PLA NPs alongwithmagnesium oxide NPs was analyzed for orthopedic engineering. The developed nanocomposites provided better mechanical properties along with osteoblast proliferation and adhesion.71
Selenium NPs loaded in PLGA particles and then coated onto bioactive glass constructs have been proved as promising candidates for bone repair and regeneration.72
Carbon nanostructures like CNTs and graphene oxide NPs has been reported for bone TE due to their low toxicity, good mechanical and biological properties, and mimicking the natural mechanical strength of bone.73 Electrical conductivity of CNTs is beneficial for bone TE as the conductive substrates can be used for cell electrical stimulation applications. These can accelerate formation of bone and its regeneration along with increasing the rate of synthesis of ECM proteins and growth factors.74 Chitosan–PLA–MWCNTs have been investigated for their applicability in bone TE. These scaffolds may serve as promising agents for bone engineering as they led to proliferation and adhesion of osteoblast cells.75 MWCNTs functionalized with hydroxyapatite have also shown enhanced bone regeneration in rabbit having defects in femur.76 In a similar way, 3D porous MWCNTs have been designed that possessed the potential of regenerative medicine to act as artificial bones for the therapeutic purpose in bone injuries. Under in vitro conditions, CNTs significantly increased the cell proliferation and exhibited better osteoconductive ability. CNTs implanted into critical-size mouse calvarial defects showed more absorption and also gradual release of protein rhBMP-2. The designed porous CNTs demonstrated good osteoconductive ability, cell attachment and proliferation capacity, and growth factor retaining ability. A triblock of maximized mechanical strength MWCNTs containing BMP-2 protein has also shown the formation of ectopic bone when implanted in mice that could serve as filler for bone defects.77 Scaffolds containing graphene oxide and hydroxyapatite NPs have been prepared using self-assembly and showed an increase in proliferation and activity of alkaline phosphatases in rat bone MSCs to stimulate mineralization and bone healing.78 Osteoblast adhesion and proliferation has also been enhanced by scaffolds containing bacterial cellulose isolated from Gluconacetobacter xylinus and MWCNTs suggesting their role in bone regeneration. Bacterial cellulose was used in bone TE due to its water retaining capacity, stability, and porosity, and it was modified with MWCNTs to increase the mechanical strength of the scaffolds for bone TE.79,80

sections.heading: PANCREAS TE
sections.text:
Pancreas is an organ that serves the functions of both endocrine and exocrine units. The endocrine components such as
6 SINGLA ET AL. NANOBIOMATERIALS FOR TISSUE ENGINEERING APPLICATIONS
α, β, δ, and ε cells that secret hormones into the body and are vital for life. β-cells are mainly responsible for secreting insulin in the body. The defects in β-cells lead to diabetes mellitus type 1 disease. Various strategies using TE have been employed during the last decades for the replacement of damaged cells by better understanding the complex microenvironment of β-cells.81 Through pancreas TE, development of a bioengineered pancreas has been achieved by appropriate combination of cells, biomaterial scaffolds, and biologically active molecules that could help in islet regeneration and transplantation as an alternative avenue for diabetes therapy.82,83 Islet transplantation also has certain limitations like lack of islet donors, difficulty in isolation of islets, decrease in viability during isolation, and damage of intra-islet vasculature.84 In the initial days of transplantation, alternative transplantation sites and supportive scaffolds were used in order to minimize the immunological responses and also to increase the islet viability, but still the viability issues exist. In the recent era, nanotechnological approaches were implanted to design NMs for repair and regeneration of pancreatic islets.
In this respect, nanotechnological efforts were made to study the effect of collagen I nanofibrils in combination with nicotinamide and exendin-4 for the repair of defected pancreatic islets. The developed structure was able to promote differentiation of MSCs into insulin producing cells and also
showed strong action for islet regeneration in rats with type-2 diabetes mellitus.85 Here, nicotinamide is a poly(ADPribose) synthetase inhibitor that induces pancreatic progenitor cells into insulin-secreting cells, whereas exendin-4 can inhibit the apoptosis induced by lipotoxicity in in vitro pancreatic cell line. Another report revealed that heparinbinding peptide amphiphile nanofibers delivered VEGF and FGF that significantly enhanced the density of blood vessels and also increased islet engraftment to facilitate islet transplantation.86 Likewise, VEGF and FGF delivered by HBPAs nanofiber gels also resulted in enhancement of cell vascularization, viability, and function. The study also suggested that growth factor delivery from nanofiber gels may serve to treat diabetes type 1 in islet transplantation.87 Peptide amphiphile nanofibers incorporated with peptide mimetic for glucagon-like peptide 1 stimulated insulin production and proliferation of insulinoma cells suggesting their role to promote the viability and function of β-cells.88 In another study, heparin mimetic peptide amphiphile nanofiber gels were reported to enhance viability and function of pancreatic islets for improving islet transplantation efficiency. Peptide amphiphiles nanofibers form a 3D network-like structure in aqueous environment, which resemble natural ECM to enhance angiogenesis for islet transplantation.89
Laminin-coated electrospun polyamide nanofibers resulted in marked improvement in response of insulin secretion by
JOURNAL OF BIOMEDICAL MATERIALS RESEARCH PART B: APPLIED BIOMATERIALS | MONTH 2019 VOL 000B, ISSUE 0 7
REVIEW ARTICLE
islets cultured with these nanofibers. The study findings depicted that these nanostructures along with laminin can be used to maintain the function of islets of Langerhans under in vitro conditions.90 Culturing of islets encapsulated with 3D peptide nanofiber hydrogel scaffolds has shown improved viability and insulin secreting function. Nanofiber scaffolds has also prolonged the survival time of islets under in vitro culture conditions.91

sections.heading: LIVER TE
sections.text:
Liver is the largest internal organ in human beings performing the functions of digestion. Acute liver failure occurs suddenly and progression of this disease can even lead to failure of many other organs and individual’s death.92,93 End-stage liver disease can only be treated by liver transplantation.94 When a patient is diagnosed with liver failure, only a limited treatment options are there. Increasing demand of liver donors leads to the ways for looking into alternative approaches using TE for treatment. Hepatocytes are the primary functional cells that play the major function in liver.95 In case of injury, liver possess regenerative tendency as the hepatocytes maintain their regenerative capacity throughout the life. Hepatocytes transplantation is anticipated to be an effective method to substitute liver functions. Due to the shorter survival time of transplanted hepatocytes, emphasis has been put on hepatocyte transplantation studies to get the better functions of transplanted hepatocytes and the better liver regeneration of patients with acute liver failure (96). Understanding of complex architecture of liver offers opportunities for liver TE to develop strategies like scaffolds, micro/nanotechnology, in situ regeneration, and cell patterning to develop suitable ECMs for hepatocyte culture to maintain high level of liver function.
Nanotechnology is in a stage of infancy to design NMs for hepatocyte production or hepatocyte repair and replacement. Nanofibers/NPs possess the structural similarity to natural ECMs, and also their mechanical properties are beneficial for liver tissue regeneration. In this context, a study carried out by Chen et al. have reported that positively chargedmesoporous silica NPs successfully delivered hepatocyte nuclear factor 3β plasmid DNA. The treated-induced pluripotent stem cells exhibited differentiation into hepatocyte-like cells, thereby suggesting the role of these NPs for gene delivery to promote the production of hepatocyte-like cells.97 Similarly, polyethyleneimine-modified seleniumNPs have been known to deliver important growth factors for the differentiation of mouse embryonic stem cells into hepatocyte-like cells and also to restore the liver injury, serving a role in liver regeneration.98 Transplantation of bone marrow stem cells with a combination of hepatocyte growth factor incorporated into chitosan NPs has resulted in enhancement of differentiation of bone marrow stem cells into hepatocytes for the treatment of liver cirrhosis.99
Curcumin encapsulated in polymeric NPs of N-isopropylacrylamide, vinylpyrrolidone, and acrylic acid synthesized by free-radical mechanism were reported to attenuate chronic hepatic injury by increasing total glutathione level and inducing stellate cell apoptosis.100 Another approach illustrated the application of a combination of nanostructured self-assembling
peptide with growth factors and cytokines to mimic in vivo microenvironment of hepatocytes under in vitro conditions. The bioartificial liver modular device maintained the viability and function of hepatocytes during long time of 90 days culture.101
Nanofibers possess properties like high porosity, small pore size, very large surface area to volume ratio that makes these nanofibers a promising candidate for liver TE. Another literature report employed the use of PCL nanofiber scaffolds that induced the differentiation of human cord blood derived unrestricted somatic stem cells into hepatogenic lineages. The study results confirmed the role of these nanofiber scaffolds in liver therapy and TE.102 Porcine hepatocytes cultured with PLA-O-carboxymethylated chitosan NPs and embedded in collagen gel has been implanted in peritoneal cavity of rats suffering from acute liver failure. The results documented that the materials were able to promote liver regeneration.103 Electrospun PCL/chitosan nanofiber scaffolds have been constructed to act as prospective material for liver TE due to their nontoxicity and ability to provide attachment to cells for their growth.104 The materials showed better biocompatibility, low immunogenicity, and greater mechanical strength due to the synergistic action of both PCL and chitosan.
Some newly developed peptide hydrogels disclosed their stimulative role in in vitro activity, with the ability to support cell attachment and stimulate the differentiation of liver progenitor cells into hepatocytes, contributing to liver tissue regeneration. Primary hepatocytes of rats cultured on MWCNTs scaffold has resulted in greater secretion of hepatocyte specific markers that suggested the applicability of these MWCNTs scaffolds in liver TE.105 CNTs are biocompatible, offer high mechanical strength, ease of functionalization, mechanically robust, and electrically conductive and provide a nanoscale, tunable fibrous topography to provide the structural reinforcement for tissue scaffolding.

sections.heading: CARTILAGE TE
sections.text:
Cartilage is a flexible, stiff, avascular, aneural, and alymphatic connective tissue that is mainly composed of chondrocytes embedded in dense and highly hydrated ECM components.106,107 Among the different types of cartilages, articular cartilage bears load in human joints and have limited capacity of self-regeneration due to absence of vasculature.108 Cartilage defects occur as a result of injury, aging and few disorders which lead to severe pain and disability. Avascular nature makes the chondrocytes and progenitor cells unable to move toward the lesion to formmatrix. Thereby, a great need was felt to develop TE-basedmaterials, having functions similar to natural cartilage so as to make them use for cartilage repair and regeneration. The development of cartilage TE strategies like biomaterial scaffolds or cell-impregnated scaffolds mainly depends on the combination of appropriate biomaterials, cell source, and stimulating factors. Over the past few decades, research has been carried out to apply various substances for cartilage repair, but outcomes are far from achieving the real structure and function of cartilages. Therefore, an urge still
8 SINGLA ET AL. NANOBIOMATERIALS FOR TISSUE ENGINEERING APPLICATIONS
arises to develop alternate nanotechnology based materials to meet the rising demands of cartilage TE.
Nanofibers are considered the most appropriate biomaterial scaffolds since fibrous morphology is able to stimulate natural collagen fibers, which have the diameter between 50 and 500 nm. Electrospun nanofibers having high porosity, high surface to volume ratio, and variable pore-size distribution resulted in promising applications in the area of TE.109
Polymeric PLGA nanofibrous scaffolds have been reported for articular cartilage reconstruction as they showed superior cell proliferation and development of ECM as compared to membrane type scaffolds. The nanofiber scaffold was sufficiently mechanically stable to withstand implantation and to support regenerated cartilage.110 In another study, electrospun nanofibers scaffolds of protein tyrosine bound to modified gelatin has supported the growth and adhesion of chondrocytes. In vitro cell culture results revealed that electrospun engineered protein scaffolds supported the attachment and growth of chondrocytes. These nanofibers also showed cell proliferation suggesting their applicability in cartilage engineering.111 Porous and biocompatible nanocomposite scaffolds of cellulose nanofibers stabilized using a mixture of crosslinked gelatin and chitosan has been synthesized. The developed nanocomposites possessing good cytocompatibility, high porosity, and ability to tailor mechanical properties have been proposed to provide cell attachment to chondrocytes and form ECM for cartilage engineering.112 In another report, PLA–PCL yarn/collagen I/hyaluronate nanofibers have been developed for cartilage TE. The prepared nanofibers induced the attachment, proliferation, and differentiation of bone marrow MSCs into chondrocytes.113 Likewise, chondroitin sulfate immobilized onto PCL nanofibers has been designed as a scaffold for cartilage repair.114 Similarly, collagen–PVA nanofibers electrospun on collagen sponge has been demonstrated to work for cartilage regeneration. This bilayered nanofibrous structures showing high tensile strength allowed the proliferation of cultured chondrocytes.115 Nanostructures of PLGA and titania also possessed the capacity to stimulate the surface and chemical properties of cartilage and to enhance the chondrocyte adhesion.116 Another strategy used the designing of glycosaminoglycans like glycopeptide nanofibers scaffolds for increasing the differentiation of MSCs into chondrocytes. These nanofiber scaffolds can act as stem cell-based therapy of cartilages as they can mimic the functions of hyaluronic acid.117
Carbon NMs have been used for TE due to its biocompatible nature and high mechanical strength. Another type of 3D nanostructure-based on MWCNTs and PLA scaffolds has been developed to mimic natural ECMs and to facilitate bone marrow MSCs chondrogenesis for cartilage reconstruction. These scaffolds showed a remarkable rise in mechanical strength of natural cartilage. The cells cultured with PLA/MWCNTs nanostructures after 2 weeks showed highest synthesis of glycosaminoglycans. Graphene-based materials having different physicochemical properties are known for influencing the interaction between biomolecules and the material surface. Figure 4, gives a glimpse of some of the properties of graphene-based materials used for different TE
applications. Graphene nanoplates and single walled CNTs (SWCNTs) incorporated into PCL scaffolds has been noticed to improve cell adhesion, proliferation, and differentiation of chondrocytes for cartilage formation.118,119

sections.heading: CARDIAC TE
sections.text:
Heart failure due to myocardial infarction is the foremost cause of deaths world-wide.120 Myocardium is the important layer of muscular cardiac tissue which is composed of myocytes. These cardiac myocytes have the tendency to selfcontract that is critical for maintaining pumping action of heart.121 Damage to cardiomyocytes may cause heart failure, thereby it is indeed important to develop curative drug therapies for the treatment of heart failure. Heart transplantation is thought to be the only solution for the replacement of damaged heart.122 However, there is a serious limitation of organ shortage for transplantation technique due to lack of graft donors and also immunosuppression.123 Cardiac TE is a promising strategy with an aim to repair and reconstruct the infarct cardiac tissues with 3D cell-based grafts, through production of in vitro engineering of cardiac tissues for implantation, and development of biomaterials to promote cell recruitment, growth, and vascularization.124 Furthermore, nanotechnology can be applied to construct NMs for cardiac myocytes TE. Various nanosized biomimetic structures have been utilized for the tissue regeneration process through cell/drug delivery, such as electrospun scaffolds, self-assembling peptides, peptide amphiphiles, and layer-bylayer (LbL) complexes, as shown in (Figure 5).125,126
The morphology of scaffolds is crucial in providing guidance cues for cellular regulation. The high surface area to volume ratio of nanofibers scaffolds lead to the interconnected porous networks which assist in nutrition perfusion and diffusions. Additionally, fiber diameter in nanometer scale resembles the architecture of natural cardiac ECM and thus facilitates cell retention, proliferation, and differentiation.127 A co-polymeric nanocomposite scaffold fabricated by PLA/PCL/silk fibrin and Aloe vera has shown potential for the infarcted myocardium regeneration as cardiac cells, which showed 42% increase in proliferation after 9 days of culture with nanocomposites.128
Other electrospun nanofibers consisted of poly(glycerol sebacate)-zein served as attractive candidates in cardiac patch applications for cardiac TE.129 Chitosan/carbon nanofibers-based scaffolds have been used for enhancing bioactivity and properties of neonatal cardiac tissues.130 In another study, AuNPs deposited onto fibrous decellularized omental matrix has been used to engineer cardiac cells. Cardiac cells showed an aligned morphology, conductivity, striations, and superior function suggesting the role of these NPs for treating myocardial infarction.131 Likewise, Au nanorods incorporated into gelatin methacrylate hydrogels (MHs) has been synthesized. Here, Au nanorods tend to impart bettermechanical strength and conductivity to the hydrogel scaffolds. The cardiomyocytes seeded on these scaffolds has shown an increase in cell viability, adhesion, metabolic activity, cell–matrix interactions for cardiac patch applications.132 In a similar manner, AuNPs bound to collagen scaffolds having nanoscale stiffness has promoted the functions
JOURNAL OF BIOMEDICAL MATERIALS RESEARCH PART B: APPLIED BIOMATERIALS | MONTH 2019 VOL 000B, ISSUE 0 9
REVIEW ARTICLE
of myocytes and increased the intercalated disc assembly to act as a better candidate for cardiac TE.133 CNTs incorporated with poly(octamethylenemaleate (anhydride) 1,2,4 butane tricarboxylate has also served for cardiac TE. The cardiac tissues have resulted in an increase in excitation threshold with these moldable elastomeric materials.134 MWCNTs/PLGA electrospun nanofibers have resulted in increased viability, cell elongation, troponin, and α-actinin formation in cultured cardiomyocytes.135 In another study, electrically conductive nanofibers formed by CNTs incorporated into gelatin MHs have resulted in an improved cardiac cell adhesion, mechanical strength, electroactivity, and organization to construct cardiac tissues.136 Likewise, SWCNTs has been incorporated into collagen matrix to enhance function of cardiac myocytes. SWCNTs have stimulated the intercalated disc assembly through β1-integrin-mediated FAK/ERK/GATA4 pathway.137 Another approach using Al/Al2O3 nanowires has opened a new pathway for large-scale production of contractile myocardial grafts by maintaining orientation of cardiomyocytes for cardiovascular TE. Polyurethane and ethyl cellulose-based nanofibrous scaffolds have also been reported for cardiac TE.138 A different approach has described the use of trace amounts of silicon nanowires for incorporation into scaffold free cardiac spheroids and resulted in structural advancement and maturation of cardiomyocytes required for cardiac tissue regeneration.139

sections.heading: VASCULAR TE
sections.text:
Cardiovascular diseases especially coronary artery disease or atherosclerosis may cause obstruction of blood vascular system.140 Atherosclerosis is another severe disease associated with the plaque formation in the blood vessels leading to thickening of walls and ultimately decreases the blood flow.141 Blood vessels (arteries and veins) transport blood to supply nutrients and oxygen to all the body parts. Blockage of these vessels is the cause of deaths worldwide.142 Under
10 SINGLA ET AL. NANOBIOMATERIALS FOR TISSUE ENGINEERING APPLICATIONS
these circumstances, blood vessel replacement at the macrocirculatory level and angiogenesis is required at microcirculatory level to restore the normal blood flow rate. Bypass surgeries are the common procedures that are adopted for revascularization of coronary and peripheral vascular bed.143 For the replacement of small diameter vessels, use of autografts is commonly followed. Autograft/allograft use has several limitations such as lack of tissue donors, anatomical differences, and related immunogenicity. To overcome all these drawbacks, there is a requirement of suitable material having similar structural composition to that of natural blood vessels which should possess the appropriate mechanical strength along with vasculature compatible with host tissue.144 Vascular TE has emerged an alternative field that involves multidisciplinary approaches and technologies to construct biomaterials or scaffolds of native or synthetic polymers for new vascular grafts to maintain function after implantation. The development of nanotechnology may serve as promising approach to improve the scope for vascular TE by preparing scaffolds that can mimic the architecture of natural human tissues at the nanoscale.
To achieve this end, ultrathin fibers produced by the electrospinning process represent an attractive approach to fabricate scaffolds for tissue-engineering applications. The nanofibrous scaffold bears a high surface area-to-volume ratio that provides more substrate for cell attachment. All these features are advantageous for tissue ingrowth.145 Electrospun PLA/PCL nanofibers having diameter 400–800 nm have been synthesized to mimic the natural environment of ECM. Human smooth muscle and endothelial cells cultured with these nanofiber scaffolds showed cell proliferation and proper attachment and also maintained their shape that suggested the role of these scaffold as vessel substitutes.146
Another effort was made to develop collagen blended
PLA/PCL nanofiber scaffolds so as to mimic ECM in terms of morphology and chemistry. Human coronary artery endothelial cells (HCAEC) seeded onto these scaffolds showed viability and cell adhesion suggested the potential of these NMs for vessel TE.147 In a different study, polystyrene nanospheres coating onto PLGA nanostructures has been done to maintain the roughness of PLGA surfaces. These surfaces led to promotion of fibronectin interactions and adhesion of vascular cells for the success of vascular grafts.148 PLGA NPs showing long release profiles of ovalbumin could also serve in cardiovascular engineering. Figure 6 shows vascular tissue construction through direct microperforation using a laser on surface patterned PCL films.149,150 Another type of electrospun nanofiber scaffolds containing chitosan and PCL has also suggested the role in blood vessel replacement as they promoted the cell attachment, growth, and proliferation of human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs).151
Using a different approach, decellularized porcine abdominal aortic tissue combined with AuNPs has been developed for vascular repair.152 TiO2 nanotubes with fine-tuned surface properties has been prepared to provide the surface for attachment of HCAEC and also improved the activation and proliferation of these cells required for improving the performance of vascular implants for TE applications.153 Another 3D polymeric porous and biodegradable PCL nanofiber scaffold precoated with osteoblasts has resulted in organization of endothelial cells and also quickened the speed of reorganization due to sustained release of VEGF–NPs incorporated into the scaffold showing their potential for enhancing vascular TE.154 Likewise, nanostructure scaffold of poly(ethylene glycol) dimethacrylate and gelatin methacrylate has been designed for vascular TE. HUVECs cultured with these nanopatterned substrates exhibited rapid cell migration, improvement in cell attachment and also retained their morphology.155 Elastin and gelatin/elastin nanocomposites
JOURNAL OF BIOMEDICAL MATERIALS RESEARCH PART B: APPLIED BIOMATERIALS | MONTH 2019 VOL 000B, ISSUE 0 11
REVIEW ARTICLE
have been proposed to play a role in vascular grafting. PLA/gelatin nanofibers have acted as a good support for the adhesion of cells and also promoted the viability and proliferation of HUVEC and human smooth muscle cells critical for vascular engineering.8,156

sections.heading: HUMAN STUDIES OR CLINICAL TRIALS OF NANOSTRUCTURES FOR DIFFERENT TE APPLICATIONS
sections.text:
In the past literature, several in vitro and in vivo experimental studies demonstrated the impact of nanocarriers mediated delivery of bioactive molecules to treat different tissue disorders. However, unfortunately, very few researchers have managed to actually reach clinical trials.157 Wood-based cellulose nanofibers dressings were tested for wound healing capacity on burn wounds of human patients. In this clinical study, the dressings were found to be highly biocompatible in the treatment of skin graft donor sites. According to preliminary comparison studies with SUPRATHEL, epithelialization rate was faster with nanofibrillar cellulose dressing.158 Recently, the bone healing tendency of a nanocomposite (DBSint) constituted of biomimetic nanostructured Mg-hydroxyapatite and human demineralized bone matrix was approved for clinical use. The clinical– radiographic and histomorphometric analysis in subjects undergoing high tibial osteotomy validated the safe and effective usage of these nanocomposites.159 An attention-grabbing clinical trial targeting on bone regeneration was recently accomplished in China Medical Hospital (NCT01323894). In this study, stem cells transfected with hydroxyapatite-based NPs were used as a strategy to improve human mesenchymal/stromal stem cells osteoblastogenesis. It is important to describe that pristine NPs employed in the trial showed no specific selectivity for bone tissue or bone tissue progenitor cells.160 In a pilot clinical study, the safety and performance of nanostructured biomimetic osteochondral scaffold containing type I collagen hydroxyapatite was tested. Clinical examination by magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated that this scaffold promoted bone and cartilage tissue restoration.161 In a different human dental clinical study, the application of nanoporous TiO2 surface-modified implants documented that thin film of TiO2 improved the adherence in early healing of the human oral mucosa and decreased bone resorption.162 A nanostructured fibrin agarose corneal substitute combining allogeneic cells was tested for clinical trial to
study its efficacy to mimic the anterior human native cornea. The initial study was conducted on five patients and results suggested that this artificial anterior human cornea can be safely implanted in patients suffering from severe trophic corneal ulcers. A phase I-II, randomized, controlled, open-label clinical trial, currently ongoing in 10 Spanish hospitals.163,164

sections.heading: CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: TE is a branch of science involving chemistry, physics, material science, engineering, and biomedicine. The main goal to use NMs such as nanofibers, NPs, nanotubes, and nanocomposites for TE applications is to achieve structural and functional reestablishment of injured or defected tissues/organs that have lost their normal function. Strategies have been developed that are intended to deliver growth factors in a controlled manner to meet the needs of tissue regeneration. Nanotechnology has immense potential to construct biomaterials for the generation of major building block of ECM of cells as NMs provide support for cell attachment, differentiation, and proliferation. The major challenge in NM-based TE is the capacity of NMs to control vasculogenesis at a nanoscale. Still, there is a need to apply more strategies to make cost-effective scaffolds containing NMs to meet the rising demands of future regenerative medicine.

The transplantation of bone tissue is highly frequent and the treatment of nonhealing bone defects requires replacement graft (autografts or allografts).(57) Treatment of bone defects by bone graft technology suffers from limitations like lack of availability of donors and also donor site morbidity.

Due to the natural nanostructure of bone, many nanotechnology-based materials have been designed to mimic bone functions with an aim to help bone formation and increased integration into the host tissue.(58) The controlled and targeted delivery of bone regenerative factors can be accomplished via NMs carrier systems to facilitate local repair at the defect site.

metadata.abstractText: Tissue engineering (TE) is an emerging field where alternate/artificial tissues or organ substitutes are implanted to mimic the functionality of damaged or injured tissues. Earlier efforts were made to develop natural, synthetic, or semisynthetic materials for skin equivalents to treat burns or skin wounds. Nowadays, many more tissues like bone, cardiac, cartilage, heart, liver, cornea, blood vessels, and so forth are being engineered using 3-D biomaterial constructs or scaffolds that could deliver active molecules such as peptides or growth factors. Nanomaterials (NMs) due to their unique mechanical, electrical, and optical properties possess significant opportunities in TE applications. Traditional TE scaffolds were based on hydrolytically degradable macroporous materials, whereas current approaches emphasize on controlling cell behaviors and tissue formation by nano-scale topography that closely mimics the natural extracellular matrix. This review article gives a comprehensive outlook of different organ specific NMs which are being used for diversified TE applications. Varieties of NMs are known to serve as biological alternatives to repair or replace a portion or whole of the nonfunctional or damaged tissue. NMs may promote greater amounts of specific interactions stimulated at the cellular level, ultimately leading to more efficient new tissue formation. © 2019 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
